thread.title: Mike Pence visits former Nazi concentration camp Dachau
thread.title_full: Mike Pence visits former Nazi concentration camp Dachau

title: Mike Pence visits former Nazi concentration camp Dachau

organizations.name: conference of presidents of major american jewish organizations

text: Share this article Share The Pence family also stopped at religious memorials at the site and later attended a church service on the camp's grounds. The vice president was accompanied on the vist by Abba Naor, a survivor of the camp, and other dignitaries. More than 200,000 people from across Europe were held at Dachau, and more than 40,000 prisoners died there. Many of them were Jewish. The camp was liberated by U.S. forces in April 1945. Holocaust survivor Abba Naor (right) accompanied Pence, his wife Karen, and daughter Charlotte (left) on their somber visit to Dachau Naor, second from left, describes the horrors of Dachau to Pence Pence and his wife Karen visit the Church of the Mortal Agony of Christ, a Catholic church at the Dachau camp memorial site Pence was raised Catholic, but is now an evangelical Christian Jewish leaders are increasingly calling on the Trump administration to respond more forcefully to a percieved rise in anti-Semitism in the U.S. Last month, Jewish centers in 27 states received telephone bomb threats. 'I think that the president helps set the tone for a country,' Malcolm Hoenlein, executive vice chairman of the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations, said in Jerusalem on Sunday. 'I'm hopeful that what he said about...addressing hate and racism of all kinds in American society will be translated into clear action. Pence, fourth from left, and his wife Karen, third from left, view historical exhibits at the memorial site to the former Nazi concentration camp Dachau A tour guide explains the history of Dachau to Pence and family. More than 200,000 people from across Europe were held at Dachau, and more than 40,000 prisoners died there Pence and his wife Karen look at exhibits at Dachau The Pences also placed a wreath beneath the International Memorial at the center of the camp. Former Vice President Joe Biden visited Dachau during a trip to Germany in 2015. Making his first overseas trip as vice president, Pence spoke to foreign diplomats and defense officials at the Munich Security Conference on Saturday and met with German Chancellor Angela Merkel and other world leaders. Pence was traveling to Brussels later Sunday for meetings on Monday with NATO and European Union officials. Pence walks over the site where the barracks were placed. A guard tower is seen behind him Pence and his wife and daughter lay a wreath to commemorate the victims of Nazi persecution The former concentration camp operated from 1933 until it was liberated by U.S. forces in 1945 Pence and his wife lay the wreath Pence with wife Karen (right) and daughter Charlotte (left) pay respects to Nazi victims The visit to Germany for the Munich Security Conference was Pence's first as vice president. After visiting Dachau, Pence was traveling to Brussels for meetings with NATO and EU officials Share or comment on this article 143
